New Records: Francisco Lindor hit the first lead-flipping postseason slam in the history of the Mets franchise.
This was the second late-inning slam in Mets history that gave them a lead in a postseason game, but the first to clinch a series.
Lindor's slam was the fifth stunning lead-flipping home run in a decade, with the Mets hitting two of them in the last week.
Key Match Events: Francisco Lindor hit a grand slam in the sixth inning to send the Mets to the NLCS.
The Mets won the game 4-1, with Lindor's slam providing all four runs.
The slam was the first lead-flipping postseason slam in the history of the Mets franchise.
Pre-Game Insights: There were no pre-game insights mentioned in the article.
Post-Match Reflections: Pete Alonso said he felt like Ricky Bobby after the slam, with his hands in the air in awe.
Ryne Stanek described the moment as 'pure emotion', with no other thought crossing his mind except 'What just happened?'
Jesse Winker called Lindor an MVP, saying he's carried the team all year and is an unbelievable player, teammate, and leader.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets have been around for 63 seasons and have played nearly 10,000 regular-season games, making Lindor's slam a rare and special moment.
Only two other men have ever hit a lead-flipping slam in the sixth inning or later in a game that clinched a series for their team.
Lindor's slam was compared to other notable lead-flipping home runs in the postseason, including those hit by Howie Kendrick, Bryce Harper, and Yordan Alvarez.
Others: The article highlighted the emotional context of the slam, saying it carried the weight of all the years of Mets October angst and released them in a rumble of cathartic thunder.
The slam was described as a magical moment that will be remembered for decades to come.
